sect1.title: {html_options}
sect1.para: {html_options} is a custom function that creates html <select><option> group with provided data. It takes care of which item(s) are selected by default as well. Required attributes are values and output, unless you use options instead.

row.entry: an array of values for dropdown
an array of output for dropdown
Yes, unless using values and output
an associative array of values and output

sect1.para: If a given value is an array, it will treat it as an html <optgroup>, and display the groups. Recursion is supported with <optgroup>. All output is XHTML compatible.
If the optional name attribute is given, the <select name="groupname"></select> tags will enclose the option list. Otherwise only the <option> list is generated.
All parameters that are not in the list above are printed as name/value-pairs inside the <select> tag. They are ignored if the optional name is not given.

example.title: {html_options}
example.programlisting:
<?php

$smarty->assign('cust_ids', array(1000,1001,1002,1003));
$smarty->assign('cust_names', array(
                              'Joe Schmoe',
                              'Jack Smith',
                              'Jane Johnson',
                              'Charlie Brown'));
$smarty->assign('customer_id', 1001);

?>
example.para: Both the above examples will output:
example.screen: <select name="customer_id"> <option label="Joe Schmoe" value="1000">Joe Schmoe</option> <option label="Jack Smith" value="1001" selected="selected">Jack Smith</option> <option label="Jane Johnson" value="1002">Jane Johnson</option> <option label="Charlie Brown" value="1003">Charlie Brown</option> </select>

example.title: {html_options} - Database example (eg PEAR or ADODB):
example.programlisting:
<?php

$sql = 'select type_id, types from contact_types order by type';
$smarty->assign('contact_types',$db->getAssoc($sql));

$sql = 'select contact_id, name, email, contact_type_id
        from contacts where contact_id='.$contact_id;
$smarty->assign('contact',$db->getRow($sql));

?>
